entry.title: Re: billing tax code determination incorrect after saving
entry.content:
Let's try other approach:

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Tax Code Redetermination Issue

I understand you're experiencing a specific issue in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition where the tax code is correct during billing document creation but changes incorrectly after saving, despite having no custom logic in the system.

Root Cause Analysis

This is a known system behavior documented in SAP Knowledge Base Article 3596118 [1]. The issue occurs when the SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER BAdI clears the pricing type during the billing document save process, even when no custom BAPI logic exists.

Technical Explanation

The Problem Pattern:

  • Tax condition is not automatically redetermined when creating a billing document
  • Pricing type in copying control is correctly set as "G: Redetermine taxes, internal prices; condition category L"
  • The issue specifically occurs during the save operation [1]

System Behavior: In S/4HANA Cloud, some calculations can only be made when the pricing result is known for all items of the document, such as determination of rounding differences or scales for group conditions [2]. This standard behavior can cause tax amounts to differ after invoice creation.

Standard System Limitation

Critical Point: The pricing type "G" is hard-coded in certain scenarios in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition [3][4]:

  • When using "Create Billing Documents" app with "Display billing documents after creation" setting enabled
  • When creating billing documents from preliminary billing documents
  • During the data transfer process in billing document creation

Available Solutions

Option 1: BAdI Implementation Review

Even though you mentioned no custom logic exists, verify if the SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER BAdI is implemented in your system. The BAdI documentation states that "all changeable attributes are initial when the BAdI is called" and requires proper copying of values from BIL_DOC, BIL_DOC_ITEM, and BIL_DOC_ITEM_CONTR to corresponding changing attributes [5].

Option 2: Alternative Billing Creation Methods

Workaround Options:

  • Use "Create Billing Documents - VF01" app instead of the standard "Create Billing Documents" app [4]
  • Disable the "Display billing documents after creation" setting in the Create Billing Documents app
  • Consider using different copying control configurations if applicable to your scenario

Option 3: Manual Tax Adjustment

Since manual tax classification changes are not possible after saving in Public Cloud, consider:

  • Making tax adjustments in preliminary billing documents before final creation [3]
  • Ensuring master data accuracy before billing document creation

Recommended Action Path

Immediate Steps:

  1. Document the exact scenario where tax code changes occur
  2. Use Pricing Analysis in the billing document to trace determination logic
  3. Test with VF01 app as an alternative creation method
  4. Review master data consistency for customer and material tax classifications

Long-term Resolution: This appears to be a system limitation rather than a configuration issue. Consider raising a support case with SAP, referencing Knowledge Base Article 3596118, to request clarification on expected system behavior or potential fixes.

The behavior you're experiencing is documented as standard system functionality in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, where certain pricing determinations are hard-coded and cannot be modified through configuration alone.

entry.title: SAP AI SKILLS ASSESSMENT RESULTS: THE MOTIVATION IS THERE, BUT ARE WE READY TO IMPLEMENT?
entry.content:
Results of the SAP AI Self-Assessment - a quick Intro

The SAP Business AI Skills Assessment measures readiness across five AI capability areas: SAP Joule (Copilot & Agents), Embedded AI Scenarios, Machine Learning Services on SAP BTP, SAP Build Joule Studio, and Responsible AI Practices.
Each area is evaluated across four dimensions: Awareness, Motivation, Knowledge, Implementation.
68 responses were collected (September-November 2025) from SAP professionals across 12 countries, spanning consultants, architects, project managers, and IT leaders in industries from manufacturing to financial services.

Who Responded

  • Geographic: 55% Germany, 10% India, 6% USA (Germanspeaking countries = 63% total)
  • Industry: 33% Service sector, 21% Discrete Manufacturing, 23% Others (IT/consulting)
  • SAP Focus: 71% S/4HANA, so it is primarily an ERP transformation story, SAP SuccessFactors as a distant second with 14.6%
  • Scale: 45% work with 1,000+ SAP users (enterprise deployments)

The AI Skills Gap (Awareness | Motivation | Knowledge | Implementation)

SAP Joule (Copilot & Agents):
  • Awareness: 3.77 | Motivation: 4.30 | Knowledge: 2.81 | Implementation: 2.38
  • Gap between Motivation and Implementation: 1.92 points

Embedded AI in SAP Cloud Solutions:

  • Awareness: 2.91 | Motivation: 4.17 | Knowledge: 2.67 | Implementation: 2.11
  • Gap between Motivation and Implementation: 2.06 points

Machine Learning Services on SAP BTP:

  • Awareness: 2.38 | Motivation: 3.93 | Knowledge: 2.24 | Implementation: 1.69
  • Gap between Motivation and Implementation: 2.24 points (the largest gap)

SAP Build Joule Studio:

  • Awareness: 2.37 | Motivation: 3.72 | Knowledge: 1.98 | Implementation: 1.88
  • Gap: 1.84 points

Responsible AI Practices:

  • Awareness: 3.16 | Motivation: 4.12 | Knowledge: 2.51 | Implementation: 2.43
  • Gap: 1.69 points
SAP AI Skills Self-Assessment results

Geographic and Industry Patterns

Top Countries by Average AI Skills:

  • India: 2.88 | Germany: 2.76 | USA: 2.73. Smaller markets (Switzerland, Austria) show wider variance. 
Top Industries:
  • Consumer Goods: 3.00 | IT/Consulting: 2.93 | Manufacturing: 2.80 | Service: 2.70
  • The Service sector's moderate scores are particularly significant given it represents one-third of respondents—this is a mainstream market, and they're just below the "somewhat agree" midpoint on implementation capability. However if we look at the sample sizes this differences probably are not statistically significant. 

KEY FINDINGS of the SAP AI Skills-Self Assessment

1. The Implementation Challenge

2-point gaps between motivation and implementation create several risks: failed pilot projects, shadow AI implementations bypassing governance, and competitive disadvantage from delayed adoption.

2. The Awareness Trap

SAP Joule has strong awareness (3.77) - probably from the strong marketing boosts. But 38% have never heard of ML Services on BTP (2.38 awareness). We know that you can't implement what you don't know.

3. The Governance thread

Responsible AI shows the second-smallest gap (1.69 points), but the absolute scores are concerning. Implementation averaging 2.43 means most organizations are deploying AI without robust ethical frameworks, data governance, or regulatory compliance measures. With AI regulations tightening globally (EU AI Act, various data protection laws), this is a compliance time bomb.

4. The S/4HANA focus

With 70.8% of respondents focused on S/4HANA, the AI skills gaps impact the success of organizations' most critical ERP transformations. S/4HANA's embedded AI capabilities and Joule integration aren't "nice-to-have" features—they're core value propositions. Missing these capabilities means organizations are upgrading infrastructure while leaving innovation value on the table. 

CRITICAL ANALYSIS

These results suggest the SAP ecosystem is approaching a skills crisis in Business AI. Here's why:

  • Talent scarcity: Only 6-17% can implement AI solutions. 
  • The cost of delay: While teams are "motivated" (4.0+), competitors with implementation skills may already deploying and iterating. 
  • Skills Cluster Together: 8 strong correlations were found between AI capabilities. The strongest was between ML Services ↔ Joule Studio (somehow common-sense that technical skills go together). So you could build cross-capability curricula.
  • False comfort: Awareness does not equal readiness. 
  • Ungoverned experimentation: High motivation (4.12) + low governance & implementation skills (2.43) means that teams might rush to "do AI" without frameworks. 
  • Organization Size is Irrelevant: There is no correlation (ρ = -0.04, p = 0.74) between company size and capability.
  • The "Dangerous Enthusiasm" Cohort: 12.4% are highly motivated but lack fundamental knowledge. This implies the risk: of ungoverned deployments → failed pilots → AI resistance. 

I also did some deep statistical analysis (ANOVA, Regression and Correlation tests) and the key implications by Claudes 4.5 deep research is something  I could not formulate better.  

"Replace awareness metrics with deployment capability. Use Outcome based criteria like productive deployment, not exam scores. THE ONE ACTION: Stop measuring readiness by surveys. Promote and measure actual deployment capability. "

CALL TO ACTION: CLOSE THE AI SKILLS GAP

What does that implicate for individuals? I suggest a 3-Step Action Plan:

  1. Assess yourself honestly - Take the self-assessment

  2. Prioritize your own learning path by topic & role 

    • Architects/Consultants --> Joule + Embedded AI + Responsible AI
    • Developers --> ML Services on BTP + Joule Studio + the Certification
    • Project Managers --> Governance + awareness across all areas
    • IT Managers --> Strategic awareness + investment decisions

  3. Build implementation skills: Motivation + knowledge without practice = continued gap

You find the Assessment and a selection of SAP AI Learning offerings here on this landingpage (if you are german-speaking: check out this blog) .  

Call to Action for Companies

Here is a suggested AI Enablement Strategy:

  1. Baseline assessment across teams (use the same framework)
  2. Role-based learning paths (not everyone needs everything)
  3. Hands-on labs, projects and POCs (application skills come only via practice & reflection) to convert theoretical experts
  4. Give room for Peer-Learning (Communities, Learning circles, Workshops where people can learn from each other)
  5. Identify internal champions (leverage your AI ambassadors, e.g. implementation ready professionals)
  6. Address awareness first as everyone needs to understand AI basics - but build in hands-on practice for everyone
  7. Establish Responsible AI governance now (not after deployment)

Call to Action for SAP Partners

  • Enable selected resources in your SAP services Team to avoid the awareness-implementation gap and support your customers in closing their skills-gap e.g. with PoCs, pilots etc. 
  • Set up SAP Business AI Discovery workshops to find out feasible, value adding AI use cases.   
  • Build genuine implementation expertise while the market remains stuck in awareness/knowledge phases. This really can be a differentiator. 

Stop doing the following

  • Awareness-only training (creates 73.7% leakage) 
  • Measuring success by course completion (this is just input-related - no outcome)
  • Assuming large (resource rich) organizations are more ready

For a consolidated List of recomendations see also my SAPNews feature: 7 Tips for Developing SAP AI Skills.

CONCLUSION

The SAP Business AI Skills Assessment results reveal an interesting analysis. Motivation is high—higher than awareness in some cases —indicating AI's strategic importance. But the implementation skills lag dangerously behind. One explanation could be, that individuals are highly motivated, but the organizational speed of AI implementation lacks behind. Obviously using AI Tools for improving individual productivity is faster and simpler than re-engineering processes or embedding AI. 

For individuals, this gap represents career opportunity - they can build implementation skills now while the market is undersupplied.
For companies, this gap represents a risk: competitors who close the gap faster will capture AI's competitive advantages while you're still "motivated to learn more." Many of the learning offerings are even free. 
For the SAP ecosystem broadly, this gap represents an urgent enablement challenge. We can't realize the promise of SAP's Business AI investments if the professionals who must implement them lack the skills to do so.
But this is actually good news. People are highly motivated to use SAP Business AI and its components. To foster motivation is always one of the most difficult parts in digital adoption. Knowledge and skill gaps can be closed. Awareness can be built. So leverage this situation and the motivation - check out the curated SAP AI training and learning offerings. Start learning today or ask your teams to develop SAP AI capabilities. 
 
For questions and feedback please use the comments below.

entry.title: Re: Change the remitter name (payer name / 振込元の依頼人名) only...
entry.content:
Good day @Linh_NguyenThiThao 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/9d271749cf1148058b9acd9e0d8bf02a/158e8b6aefb8430d89d28960d33818ac.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/164aaa06151b4106b7bc163efe97902a/ed166f63a4de44afab81168bb8bab9ae.html?locale=en-US

Answer to question 1:

No. There is no supported BAdI, SSCUI or configuration in public cloud that allows you to override the remitter name at the vendor level. These restrictions are in place due to the clean-core principle.

Answer to question 2:

Yes, that is the recommended workaround. You basically create a new Payment Method through SSCUI 101044, set a custom remitter name for that method and assign the new payment method only to the specific vendor in their master data. You can achieve isolating the remitter name for that supplier.

Answer to question 3:

Yes, it is a public cloud limitation. I have had a few instances, especially Japan related use cases and the recommendation is to make use of a multiple payment method.

In summary, the reason why the public cloud does not allow you to enhance the remitter dynamically through Payment Medium Cloud BAdIs is because:

  1. Firstly, the system populates the payer field during proposal and this is based on a hard-coded logic.
  2. Secondly, public cloud BAdIs such as Payment Medium tend to add fields, while Payment Mediums allow file name change within limited file-level.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to call a RAP action from your Controller Extension
entry.content:
Traditionally to improve performance of a Fiori application the roundtrips to the backend (OData Service) should be minimal. To achieve this, we can push some processing logic to the frontend, This Blog explores one of the option to do that.

RAP Action

One of RAP’s powerful capabilities is the concept of actions — custom operations tied to a business object that let you implement domain-specific logic in ABAP using the behaviour implementation class (e.g. “approve order,” “mass update statuses,” “trigger workflow,” etc.) rather than relying purely on standard CRUD behaviour.

When you want to expose such actions in the UI of your RAP based Fiori App, there are two ways you can do it,

  • Using OData Annotations
  • Using Controller extensions

This blog covers a basic scenario of adding a custom button on the list page.

Using OData Annotations

Using OData annotation is the easier way out and suggested by SAP. SAP don’t want ABAPers to think much about the front end, that’s where the Fiori elements come in which is standard UI5 library to deploy Fiori apps, using which any ABAPer can create a Fiori app without have any knowledge about UI5.

Fiori elements generate the Fiori app in runtime using

  • OData Annotations
  • OData Service
  • Standard Fiori Floorplans.

So, adding your annotations in the below manner to your CDS will add the custom action on your Fiori App.

For sake of simplicity, I am using a static action

Below is the metadata extension file containing the UI annotations

Result,

 

You can write the business logic for this action in the behaviour implementation class

Using Controller extensions

If your requirement is not fulfilled by using the OData Annotations, for instance you want to call multiple actions using a single button or push some processing to your frontend rather than the backend (Your OData Service). You can use application modeler to add a custom button in the front end.

You can add a custom button using Application Modeler and add a handler method in your Controller extension. Using this handler method, you can call the same custom action from the RAP OData V4 service.

In the below example I am adding a custom button on the list page in the table toolbar.

Make Sure that you have created a Controller Extension for the page you are adding the custom button to, you can do that using the application modeler as well

Once the custom action is added you can add the below logic to call the custom action of the OData Service, you can replace the endpoint as per your OData service

     

OnActionPress: async function() {
// Calling a custom action of RAP Bobj using Controller ext
console.log("OnActionPress");
// Getting service URL
var model = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getModel();
var url = model.sServiceUrl;

// Making a GET call to fetch CSRF Token
var getTokenResp = await fetch( url, { method: "GET", headers: 
{ "X-CSRF-Token": "Fetch", Accept: "application/json" },credentials: "same-origin"  });
var token = getTokenResp.headers.get("x-csrf-token");	

// Calling Custom action by making a POST call
var uploadEndpoint = url + "Y_C_UTILAPP_PG/SAP__self.Upload";
const uploadResp = await fetch(uploadEndpoint, {
                        method: "POST",
                        headers: {
                            "Content-Type": "application/json",
                            Accept: "application/json",
                            "X-CSRF-Token": token
                        },
                        credentials: "same-origin"
                    });
console.log("Calling a custom action of RAP Bobj using Controller ext"); }

Result

A similar custom button will be created

Pressing this button will trigger the handler method ‘OnActionPress’ which will make the POST call triggering the same ‘Upload’ static action of the RAP Business Object.

 

PS: Thank you for reading. I’ll be writing more blogs soon on RAP, OData, UI5, and flexible programming languages — hope to see you there!

entry.title: SAP Mobile Start V2.5 - Release update brings UX and To-Do enhancements
entry.content:
With the recently released version 2.5, SAP Mobile Start adopts Apple's new Liquid Glass design language and provides several enhancements for To-Dos.

Let´s start with Liquid Glass. With Liquid Glass, Apple has unified its platform design language across Apple’s ecosystem of products. Liquid Glass provides a much more dynamic and expressive user experience and complements the experience of latest Apple devices like the Apple iPhone 17 – e.g. the round edges of the latest devices are now also reflected in the new design language.  

What does this mean for our iOS users of SAP Mobile Start? First, you get a more dynamic user experience, but most important is that you get more space on the screen as the navigation bar collapses if it is not needed. Also, the content scrolls below the navigation and header bar.

 Screenshot: New Liquid Glass design of SAP Mobile Start 

Another small but worth to mention UX enhancement is that empty pages are not shown on the App Screen anymore. In the past, the app showed empty pages that did not have any mobile app assigned. With the new release, those are not shown anymore. 


On the To-Dos screen, you get an additional To-Do filter option with the new release. This allows you to filter your to-dos by semantic groups defined in Task Center. For instance, you can have a group "Procurement", that automatically brings together to-dos from different source systems into one streamlined view. Furthermore, you can switch from the standard card view to a new compact view that provides you more flexibility to choose the view of your to-dos, based on the amount of to-dos you are dealing with. Please check our SAP Help documentation for details.  
Screenshot: To-Do screen with new filter and view type

I hope you will enjoy these features in SAP Mobile Start.

For further information on the new topics, please check our SAP Mobile Start documentation.

SAP Mobile Experience offers intelligent native mobile solutions that help businesses build more efficient, resilient and sustainable end-to-end processes, improving people’s work life wherever they are.

Visit SAP Mobile Experience Community Page and click “follow” to get the latest development and innovation of our solutions. We look forward to hearing about your experience with setting up the solution in your landscape; please do share your thoughts and comments below. Enter here for additional questions regarding SAP Mobile Experience Applications.

Want to be notified? Check your profile settings to ensure you have your settings activated.

Issue: Payment on Account amount is not updated in Project Billing Request.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Payment on Account A001 amount is not reflecting in P...
entry.content:
Product A001 has a default Account Assignment Group of X6. G/L account 41007100 by default is assigned to X6.

Project Billing only checks against G/L accounts maintained under Cost Element Group YBPS_R030 for On-Account Issued. G/L account 41007100 should be assigned to YBPS_R030.

Check in app Display Line Items in General Ledger that the Invoice was posted against 41007100. If not, then correct the above configuration.

entry.title: Re: regarding Backorder Processing (BOP)
entry.content:
Good day @S-O 

This Blog has some good insights: Backorder Processing in advanced ATP

In summary, BOP does not perform a final ATP confirmation for orders that are credit-blocked in public cloud and the reason is:

  • When you create a sales order and it exceeds your credit limit, the system blocks the order from ATP confirmation and thereby no delivery process is triggered.
  • Even if stock then becomes available at a later time, BOP will still consider the blocked Sales orders as a valid demand when the simulation runs and may then reserve inventory for them.
  • However, because the credit block is not changed, the system does not update the quantities confirmed in VA03, even if your BOP shows “Credit Warning and Saved”

Technically the system tries to differentiate the various scenarios.

Step 1: You create Sales Orders e.g., in your case 1 through to 3, without stock, the system technically does not confirm due to the lack of material/stock availability.

Step 2: In a situation where Order are Credit blocked; the system suspends the ATP check and applies the credit block.

Step 3: In a situation when inventory becomes available; the BOP still includes blocked Sos in the demand.

Step 4: Then, the BOP run process Sales Orders; the logs may show Credit Warning and the system simulates reservation.

Step 5: In this case VA03 will still show 0 confirmed quantity because the credit block is still in place.

Step 6: Thereafter the Product Availability App shows that you reserved, which means BOP has reserved inventory virtually.

Step 7: Now your new SO4 sees no stock because inventory appears consumed by earlier blocked Sales Orders.

So, while technically there is no confirmation in the system, BOP holds inventory virtually for the cred-blocked orders until you either unblock or reject them.

Based on your description, I understand your goal is to free up stock for new orders. If that assumption is correct then my suggestion is to:

  1. Either release the Credit Block in your system (Once you have released the system, it will trigger a new ATP check and the system will confirm available quantities.) or,
  2. You exclude Blocked Orders from your BOP (This will prevent BOP from reserving stock for orders that are not eligible for confirmation)

Here is a insightful answer to a similar community question: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/credit-blocks-after-atp-bop-run/qaa-p/12697502#M4135937

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Set up custom security logs
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I have a request from a customer who needs to implement monitoring on the following events to comply with their internal Security requirements :

  • User logons and logon attempts (successful and failed)
  • User account modifications (creation, modification, deletion, role changes)
  • Access to sensitive data and critical transactions
  • Unauthorized access attempts (authorization failures)
  • System configuration and security parameter changes
  • Privileged user activities (administrators)

Their Security requirements are the following:

  1. Confirmation that the Security Audit Log is enabled on their tenant with capture of critical security events
  2. Access to the “Display Security Audit Log” Fiori application for security/audit teams
  3. Documentation on the complete list of events captured in their Cloud edition
  4. Ability to export these logs to enable automated security alerting and monitoring

I was advised that CAS (Cloud Application Services) could address these kind of needs but these are not for "one shot" request, CAS are indeed used for recurring activities ; I also raised a CISA request but the URL they've provided seems to be outdated. 

Thanks much in advance

entry.title: Re: Seamless Integration: Connecting Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity Management with S/4HANA Customer Pro
entry.content:
Hey Prasad and David, thanks for your contribution and the information. Sounds like a cool solution!

We are currently trying to implement something similar. I would be particularly interested to know what criteria you used to set the event notification and whether the communication system is the same communication system that you integrated at the master data and transaction data level. In your case, that would be S/4.

In our scenario, we want to call a custom iFlow (own endpoint on the CPI) based on an update in the account object, which in turn executes customer-specific mapping/logic and updates the account API in V2 itself. To do this, we deployed the iFlow and generated a custom endpoint. The CPI is the same one that you have already used to set up the business partner integration and successfully send confirmation messages to S/4.

However, when we click on “Test connection” in the “Send Event Notification” section, we get the error message “Connection failed.”

I would be very grateful for any insights into exactly how you set up your communication system and path, also in comparison to your standard integration (your step 1).

In “Path,” we have maintained the CPI URL, once with “https” and once without, both times without success. Unfortunately, the help guide does not provide any further information. https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SALES/ea5ff8b9460a43cb8765a3c07d3421fe/b574855d4adc4c40a50db57ca97b1c53.html?locale=en-US#send-event-notifications

Regards
